detailedReviewData.description:
review this code
{cs:id=49667|rep=FE}: CRUC-1604: add completed reviewers set to frx data for API and REST NONE: check that author is not null when creating review via API
detailedReviewData.name: CRUC-1604: add completed reviewers set to frx data for API and REST

generalCommentData.message: Is this providing read-only data about user completion, or can we also modify completion status per frx per user?
This is read only at present -- and also only includes reviewer status, not author/moderator.
Pawel, Wojtek -- note that there's some discussion of whether these changes are a suitable API -- what's your opinion?

Sorry for slow reply. Somehow I missed this review in my mailbox notification storm. OT: doing this review was a nightmare. I tried 3 browsers on my Ubuntu: Opera 10, FF 3.5.x and FF 3.0.x (_without_ Firebug) and everywhere the performace was terrible. I could scarcely scroll the screen. Auto saving took ages, everything was completely unresponsive. 3 minutes reading and writing, 30 minutes waiting for my browser to wake up. I hope that something is going wrong with EAC Crucible instance itself. Just FYI.

That's interesting, I don't think we've observed that problem on FF3.5 here. Do you think it could be related to a slow link to contegix -- i.e. the polling and ajax stuff is taking a long time, and some of the UI assumes that it woudln't?

tried today with a different (30Mbit) internet connection in our office from two different computers. It works really well from Firefox 3.5.6 on Ubuntu 9.10. It works terribly slow (next to stall) on my Ubuntu 8.10 with Firefox 3.5.5 and Firefox 3.0.15. I restarted the system and run just a single app - the browser. Any other web pages work well for me on this system. Both computers use the same internet connection and access the same review - this one.
No idea what is going on.

Just to be 100% sure: we can now track completion status of the moderator as well. Could you confirm? What does it mean then?
Generally I don't like too much this approach, as it probably uses a lot of unnecessary/inapplicable attributes for various kinds of participants (I believe that moderator attribute can be {{true}} only for one participant, the same goes for author). It also introduces duplication with <reviewers> (which also have {{completed}} attribute) and {{<author>}} {{<moderator>}} elements. Is it intentional? Are there any plans to remove now redundant whole {{reviewers}} section or even {{author}} or {{moderator}} elements?

The {{completed}} element inside a participant indicates that the participant has read the FRX -- this is unrelated to a reviewer completing the review (a reviewer can complete without having read any FRXs, and reading all FRXs doesn't imply completion of the review). This completion information is also available for the author and moderator.
It does duplicate {{author}} and {{moderator}} elements, but those are provided for non-detailed views of a review, while the {{participants}} data is only shown when you request a detailed response, and only exists if the review contains at least one FRX, so I think keeping {{author}} and {{moderator}} is a good idea.

# We could add a {{<participants>}} element to each comment to indicate who has read it. If this would be useful to the plugin now, please raise an issue. # I don't think it's a privacy problem -- anyone else? # I agree -- I'll remove those # Crucible doesn't show this information to other users at present -- just the completion percentage graphic. But I think it's worth providing the raw information.
Ad 1. OK. I'll raise as soon as we are close to be able to consume this data on the client side. Now we are fighting with much more simple stuff. Ad 2-4. Cool

versionedLineCommentData.message: this should be on the superclass {{ReviewItemData}} ?

generalCommentData.message: Yes, participants are a general review concept, fixed.

versionedLineCommentData.message: this method is only used by tests... I wonder if we could make it package-scope, or even remove it?

generalCommentData.message:
clients can guess user's role, as we have list or reviewers, the author and moderator anyway.
However being able to tell how much given participant is advanced with completion could be a win.
We could then render in IDE a progress bar similar to the one rendered in web UI, as it gives a better indication than just a binary state for completion.
Plus it's more extensible and forward compatibile as REST itself is concerned, thus my call would be for a little POJO.

versionedLineCommentData.message: should we make this an {{expand}} field? Do we need to consider permissions when returning this data (nah prob not)

generalCommentData.message:
If you can see the review, you can see all of the participants, I think?
I don't think it needs to be {{expand}}.
if it's really costly on the server side to check this data - {{expand}} would make sense. If not - just include it.
yep all good

versionedLineCommentData.message: Do we only want to show completed reviewers, or should we have all participants who have completed?

generalCommentData.message: I don't think i makes sense to talk about "completedness" for anyone but a reviewer?

maybe. a moderator/author can be "complete" via this algorithm if they mark the frx as read (which they can do). If we consistently return moderators/authors from this method, clients will know to treat them differently?
I think if you document what it returns, then there's no issue either way.
And FisheyeReviewItemData is self-documented as {{getCompletedReviewers()}} so it's pretty clear that as it stands, it should be just reviewers.
However: the case for it returning all participants: * Imagine the connector UI, and it allows participants to mark frxes as read and unread. * It provides this checkbox to modeators, authors and reviewers (like our UI) * How does the connector UI know if the given user has already read it -- wouldn't it used frx.getCompletedParticipants() and check that list for the current user? * I believe this method should return all the info we have, either as two methods (getCompletedReviewers() and getCompletedParticipants()) or just one method (prefer the latter)
?

I think slow today, so apologies.
If Crucible lets reviewers track whether the author or moderator read reviewers' comments and this is what you mean by completedness of participants, then, yes, I would love to have this info.
Best in one place -> getCompletedParticipants() Even better -> as an extra element in the main review data (next to username and display name of every participant listed).

so could you quickly tell me how one should understand and visualise this state ("completedness") of moderator and/or the author? When can it be set to true? Currently Crucible web UI does not seem to show completedness for the author or moderator. Why?
Should we rename this to {{read}}? It is indicated in the Crucible UI by the boldness or otherwise of the file names in the tree on the review page.
Please read my other comment explaining that I misunderstood this feature. {{completed}} will be more consistent with {{completed}} flag in {{<reviewer>}} which we already have.

bq. Even better -> as an extra element in the main review data (next to username and display name of every participant listed).
That does make sense, yes?

It might make sense to add a 'completed review' flag there, but this new data is per FRX, so needs to go in {{DetailedReviewData}}. There is already a {{getCompletedReviewers}} method on {{ReviewService}}.
sorry. not sure if you are asking me Matt or others. If the former, then please rephrase your question :)
I like your "even better" suggestion -- this information should come back along with the other participant data in the main Review Data. Anyone disagree?

versionedLineCommentData.message: Having methods operating on two different UserData classes was ridiculous

strange name class for me taking into consideration that all 3 methods are about User* classes conversion and not about projects. There is nothing implying here that it has anything to do with ProjectData but the comment above :)
This wasn't hooked up to the DB!

generalCommentData.message: oi
